snippet: Proving the crime of leaving the scene of an accident is often easy; proving “moral blameworthiness” to support a more-serious crime is harder.
abstract: Court rulings in New York, which found drivers’ actions failed to show moral blame, promise to muddy already gray legal area, and may even work in favor of driver Julio Acevedo, who is charged with criminally negligent homicide after crashing his speeding car and leaving young couple and later, their baby, dead; establishing drivers' criminal behavior is difficult, since New York is adding morality as component of criminally negligent homicide in car crashes.
lead_paragraph: Proving the crime of leaving the scene of an accident is often easy; proving “moral blameworthiness” to support a more-serious crime is harder.

headline.seo: Serious Charges in Fatal Crashes Pose Challenge for Prosecutors
headline.main: Prosecutors Face Test Proving Serious Crime in a Fatal Crash
headline.print_headline: Prosecutors Face Test Proving Serious Crime in a Fatal Crash
